--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Joshua Kerievsky <jlk@...> wrote:
>
> On Fri,=
 Feb 20, 2009 at 5:25 AM, majkic@... <majkic@...> wrote:
> 
> > I need to c=
reate automated acceptance tests. Selenium seems to be
> > nice, since it a=
llows someone without much (or none at all)
> > programming experience, as =
our Product Owner to create those tests
> > with Firefox Selenium IDE plug-=
in.
> >
> > But time has come to integrate those tests to other JUnit tests=
, so
> > these can be run on CI server.
> >
> > Is there any know-how or li=
nk which could help. I already visited
> > mavenium (http://mavenium.source=
forge.net/index.html) and
> > maven2-selenium plug-in
> > site(http://mojo.=
codehaus.org/selenium-maven-plugin/index.html), but
> > documentation is no=
t quite clear, or at least I couldn't run my tests.
> >
> > As I understood=
, selenium-rc should run automatically if defined in
> > pom.xml and then S=
elenium JUnit tests should run fine. What about
> > jetty? Is it run implic=
itly, or some server should be run? If not
> > automatically, should it be =
run manually? In this case CI doesn't make
> > sense, since you have to dep=
loy application to some other server.
> >
> > Huh...too many questions, I g=
uess. I would be happy to have at least
> > some answers.
> 
> 
> In genera=
l, we much prefer Selenium Core to Selenium RC (which we
had used
> for a w=
hile).  You can write all your Selenium Core tests in JUnit and
> they'll r=
un in the browsers.  We even run our Se Core tests in
parallel for
> maximu=
m speed.
> 
> We started an eLearning album called Mastering Selenium, yet =
we
aren't very
> far along on it.  When it gets more mature, you could chec=
k it out,
if you
> like.   Just ping me about it.
> 
> -- 
> best regards,
